channel.title: Randomly closing while playing
channel.description: OK Well I don't know if this is server or client, but whenever I play a local server (I have tried like 10 different clients and sources), a few seconds after connecting the client just closes.

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Gsempire Gsempire
item.description:
@Gsempire wrote:

Just change the run.bat to run.exe in the client, you can download a converter to convert the .bat to .exe somewhere.

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @drubrkletern drubrkletern
item.description:
@drubrkletern wrote:

no problem, just use that with any 317 client it happens with, it just makes a application which is compatible with windows 7 to run 317 clients, so keep that with you

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @sckum555 sckum555
item.description:
@sckum555 wrote:

Ok thanks so much that worked!!!

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @drubrkletern drubrkletern
item.description:
@drubrkletern wrote:

  1. Ok First you need to download this - http://uppit.com/v/REKLK274

2.Open that up and click Windows 7 Coverter

3.Then You will see a line that says ( Batch File: ) Click the ( … ) on that line then a brows will pop up and go to your client folder and click your .bat that you use to run your client.

4.Then push compile.

5.Now your done! go back to your client folder and if you have a windows 7 computer you can play 317’s now and it wont crash the client.

tadah, dont flame me for copying locksmin, credits to him, i just couldnt find the post, so i just pasted it here and i had it somewere…

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

I think the file is JVM.dll, I’m not sure though could be wrong. I’ve just heard of a few people that have fixed this by doing a registry clean. Hm.

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Shorty626 Shorty626
item.description:
@Shorty626 wrote:

According to Oracle its caused by a corrupt DLL. Doesn’t really tie into the registry much but its definitely not impossible when you are talking about corrupt files.

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

This can also be caused by corrupt registry edits.

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Shorty626 Shorty626
item.description:
@Shorty626 wrote:

I did not understand that this was happening with every client and source. In that case, You need to completely uninstall the JRE, Grab a fresh copy of the newest release from the Java web page, And install it. That should solve your problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @sckum555 sckum555
item.description:
@sckum555 wrote:

So why does every client and source do this?

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Shorty626 Shorty626
item.description:
@Shorty626 wrote:

There are 35 calls to the doWalkTo method in that file. One of them is overflowing your client when you try to execute that instruction. In the best practice, you need to figure out what it is you try to do before it crashes then when it crashes you can identify which method is being called and why it is causing a buffer overflow. (This is usually something wrong with the VM though because you are getting a crash dump.)

Also check this out.

http://www.java-forums.org/eclipse/312-exception_access_violation-0xc0000005.html

Might also fix your problem.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @sckum555 sckum555
item.description:

http://pastebin.com/AteP4iHs

pastebin.com your client.java for the client and repost the link let me look at it.

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @sckum555 sckum555
item.description:
@sckum555 wrote:

Then you have to translate the article into noob language. I’m no java hacker/programmer. I’m just a guy trying to start a server for friends.

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Shorty626 Shorty626
item.description:
@Shorty626 wrote:

Read the wikipedia article I linked to better understand what happens to program execution when a buffer overflow occurs within it. Then take a look at that method and see if you notice something that might be causing it.

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @sckum555 sckum555
item.description:
@sckum555 wrote:

Can you translate that into noob please?

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Shorty626 Shorty626
item.description:
@Shorty626 wrote:

Looks like a buffer overflow in your doWalkTo method in client.java. Some value in that method is too large and it is “spilling” into the clients other memory causing it to crash. Look into your doWalkTo method.

en.wikipedia.org

Buffer overflow

In information security and programming, a buffer overflow, or buffer overrun, is an anomaly where a program, while writing data to a buffer, overruns the buffer's boundary and overwrites adjacent memory locations. Buffers are areas of memory set aside to hold data, often while moving it from one section of a program to another, or between programs. Buffer overflows can often be triggered by malformed inputs; if one assumes all inputs will be smaller than a certain size and the buffer is created ...

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Shorty626 Shorty626
item.description:
@Shorty626 wrote:

All it takes is “Oh I didn’t know that. Cool.”

On the other note let me help you.

ITS WRITTEN IN FUCKING JAVA ITS PLATFORM INDEPENDENT!

You didn’t have to download the 32Bit Runescape client or 32 Bit JRE to play did you, No.

And a 64 Bit processor will run any 32 bit code natively. Thats the point I was proving telling you that I could run 32 Bit Windows on a 64 Bit processor without doing anything different. When you go to school and have a degree in Computing then you may come back and tell me I am wrong.

EDIT: From the Wikipedia article:
A compiled Java program can run on a 32 bit or 64 bit Java virtual machine without modification. The lengths and precision of all the built in types are specified by the standard and are not dependent on the underlying architecture. Java programs that run on a 64 bit Java virtual machine have access to a larger address space.

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Shorty626 Shorty626
item.description:
@Shorty626 wrote:

Thats why I could install 32 Bit Windows on my 64 Bit processor right? Or do I need to get the 32 bit libraries for my processor first?

Read full topic

item.title: Randomly closing while playing
item.dc:creator: @Shorty626 Shorty626
item.description:
@Shorty626 wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”][quote author=Shorty626 link=topic=453703.msg3323117#msg3323117 date=1282871209]
64 Bit would work just fine. Do you have an HSERROR log in the same folder you launch the client from that you could post?
[/quote]64-bit JRE will not work fine, as the RS client is a 32-bit application.
It requires a 32-bit runtime environment. As the client was made in mostly Java, and it is a Java application, it requires the Java Runtime Environment. (JRE)[/quote]

en.wikipedia.org

64-bit computing

In computer architecture, 64-bit computing is the use of processors that have datapath widths, integer size, and memory address widths of 64 bits (eight octets). Also, 64-bit computer architectures for central processing units (CPUs) and arithmetic logic units (ALUs) are those that are based on processor registers, address buses, or data buses of that size. From the software perspective, 64-bit computing means the use of code with 64-bit virtual memory addresses. However, not all 64-bit instructi...

What was that? Read that whole section then explain yourself again please? I don’t see why you people can’t just accept the fact that you are wrong about something.

Read full topic
